items.title: This town has 3 nuclear plants. Now, it wants another one.
items.author: Nate Krieger

items.title: How Wall Street helped turn poor countries into permanent debtors
items.author: Sara Herschander

items.title: The culture war is consuming the Supreme Court
items.author: Ian Millhiser
items.summary:
- Barrett’s confirmation shifted the Court toward culture-war issues, with a 6-3 Republican majority risking anti-abortion rulings and reviving conservative causes.
- Litigants adjust when the Court moves ideologically; Mahmoud v. Taylor (2025) requires schools to give advance notice and offer opt-outs for offended lessons.
- Bruen’s unclear Second Amendment framework prolongs disputes; the culture-war focus may persist under Republican power and could fade if precedents are overturned.

items.title: 7 reasons to feel actually hopeful about the clean energy transition
items.author: Paige Vega
items.summary:
- Renewables eclipse coal in 2025: solar, wind, hydro ~34% of electricity; coal ~33%; ~380 GW new solar in six months.
- China as transition engine: domestic build-out, cheaper batteries, rooftop solar expansion driving global costs down.
- State-led momentum: ~75% of 2025 new generation from state actions; grid upgrades, affordability, EVs; bottlenecks persist.

items.title: Trump’s war on windmills, briefly explained
items.author: Cameron Peters
items.summary:
- The Trump administration halted leases for five under-construction East Coast wind-farm projects on national-security grounds, withholding details.
- The halt risks billions in investment and thousands of jobs, delaying U.S. clean-energy progress amid higher power costs.
- It questions the rationale as vague, framing it as part of Trump 2.0’s wind-energy opposition and past personal grudge, plus a court ruling against previous blocks.

items.title: Is CBS News censoring 60 Minutes?
items.author: Andrew Prokop

items.title: What makes the Great Smoky Mountains smoky?
items.author: Dolly Li
items.summary: - Explains how the Smokies got their name and notes the park's Tennessee–North Carolina border and Cherokee heritage.\n- Describes the blue hazy atmospheric effect typical of the range and its link to the microclimate.\n- Mentions Visit North Carolina sponsorship, Vox's editorial independence, and Vox's Patreon promotion.

items.title: Can you trust your brain?
items.author: Jonquilyn Hill
items.summary:
- Perception is constructed by the brain: tinnitus, the dress illusion, and pareidolia show we don’t read reality directly.
- We rely on fast, heuristic judgments from incomplete data; redundancy makes reliability high, but our certainty should be modest.
- There may be a deeper reality beyond senses, and we live in a low-dimensional view while coping with perceptual quirks.

items.title: 2025 felt like a disaster — but the numbers tell a very different story
items.author: Bryan Walsh
items.summary:
- Contrasts grim 2025 with progress: KJ Muldoon’s CPS1 gene therapy via base editing, FDA emergency use, and a patient leaving hospital after 307 days.
- Harm trends improve: homicide down ~17% H1 2025; overdoses ~80k (2024); suicides/traffic deaths down; obesity ~37% (2025); alcohol/teen drinking down; GLP-1 weight loss ~15–20%.
- Ozone progress: 99% phase-out; Antarctic hole smallest since 2019; recovery by 2040–2066; Montreal Protocol may curb warming; optimistic close.

items.title: 2025 was the year everything changed for the US and China
items.author: Joshua Keating

items.title: What does Trump’s AI czar want?
items.author: Avishay Artsy
items.summary:
- Sacks pushes a light-touch AI regime, shaping a Trump-era executive order that preserves safety yet avoids onerous rules to accelerate U.S. AI leadership.
- The piece traces his rise from Silicon Valley VC to DC power broker, with GOP donations, Trump fundraisers, and efforts to bring tech talent into the White House.
- It frames AI policy amid US–China tech rivalry, Nvidia/chip concerns, and public pushback, highlighting tensions between growth and safeguards.

items.title: The Epstein files release did nothing to clear up the scandal's biggest question
items.author: Andrew Prokop
items.summary:
- The release missed the legal deadline: thousands were published, but hundreds of thousands remain unreleased or unreviewed.
- The disclosures do little to resolve whether others were involved or Epstein trafficked victims to associates, including Giuffre's claims about Prince Andrew.
- DOJ says Epstein abused hundreds of women, but questions about credibility, related leads, or potential cover-ups remain unresolved and may stay undisclosed.

items.title: Yes, your anger and forgiveness can coexist
items.author: Sean Illing
items.summary:
- Forgiveness is overvalued as a universal fix; anger signals injustice and demands accountability rather than a failure of self-control.
- Forgiveness can coexist with anger; it's not mandatory and should not erase past harms or replace structural justice.
- The discussion links personal, political, and collective forgiveness to truth-telling, reform, and ongoing accountability in a history of racism.

items.title: How to consume the Epstein files responsibly
items.author: Andrew Prokop
items.summary:
Hundreds of thousands of Justice Department files on Jeffrey Epstein are due for release. The article cautions that investigatory documents often contain hearsay and unverified claims, so readers should pause, fact-check, and distinguish corroborated facts from rumors. It advocates careful, contextual analysis—verify dates, attendees, and the nature of contents—rather than sensational conclusions about wealth, intelligence ties, or others' involvement.
- Verify facts in the Epstein files and distinguish corroboration from rumors.
- Check dates, attendees, and the nature of the documents before drawing conclusions.
- Avoid sensational claims about intelligence ties or involvement of others; rely on official timelines and prosecutor notes.

items.title: The case against releasing the Epstein files
items.author: Ian Millhiser
items.summary: - DOJ norms shield ongoing probes and victims; releasing Epstein files could endanger victims or reveal innocents.\n- Disclosures for political advantage threaten pre-election safeguards and due process, as shown by Stevens and Clinton emails.\n- Since Epstein is dead, release could retraumatize victims, set a harmful precedent, and exceed privacy norms without proving crimes.

items.title: 9 actually good things that happened to animals this year
items.author: Kenny Torrella
items.summary:
- In schools, policy changes allow soy milk alongside cow's milk, cutting waste and aiding lactose-intolerant students of color.
- Shrimp welfare improves as retailers push for electric stunning and major certifiers ban eyestalk ablation.
- Poultry welfare advances with slower-growing chicken breeds by European producers to reduce health problems and suffering.

items.title: We need to grow the economy. We need to stop torching the planet. Here’s how we do both.
items.author: Marina Bolotnikova

items.title: What if child care could make you rich?
items.author: rebecca-gale

items.title: Trump’s attack on trans health care, briefly explained
items.author: Cameron Peters

items.title: What you need to know before the Epstein files come out
items.author: Cameron Peters

items.title: Is the Trump administration just a reality TV show?
items.author: Christian Paz
items.summary:
- Trump is treated as TV—a simulacrum with a reality‑TV hero/villain persona; the first term felt more entertaining due to cliffhangers and clashes with reporters.
- Social media reshapes celebrity and politics, fueling echo chambers; reality stars court attention to fuel careers, with followers reacting to mood over truth.
- The piece asks if media‑first, influencer‑style governance could become the new normal for the next generation of leaders.
